text: so so my name is crystal Yin I actually when I was in school I studied economics
but there was a field within microeconomics that was particularly interesting to me so it was this field
emerging field called behavioral economics and it was sort of at the intersection of economics and psychology
there's a key principle in classical economics that people are rational and they act in their own best interests and
this field was all about sort of debunking that common understanding that sometimes people are irrational and they
don't act in their best interest and that was when I first started to think about you know the relevance of what I
was thinking in this academic context to the field of user experience today I
work for an organization called the United States digital service and I work for a team there at the Department of
Health and Human Services and specifically we've been doing a lot of work with the Center for Medicare and Medicaid so for those of you who aren't
familiar the u.s. digital service is actually a start of itself were a
federal government agency and but we've only been around for about four years we
originally started after the healthcare.gov crisis when the CTO of the US at the time Todd Park recruited a
bunch of people from Silicon Valley and within his own network to come to Washington and help sort of fix
healthcare.gov and after that he and Obama thought you
know what would it look like if we had people who just knew technology that were embedded in the government from the
very start of a project instead of coming to fix it at the end once it failed because a lot of government IT
projects fail and so that's where the idea for the u.s. digital service came
to be it also came from a program that started around this time called the presidential innovation Fellows but the
key difference between this program which still exists today is that the u.s. digital service really focuses on
sending teams of people to work with agencies so if you've ever worked to win within a very large company and you felt
like you were the only person who really understood how you should be developing software or how you should be
user experience in human centered design and there were you know hundreds of people around you or thousands of people
around at you who wanted to plan every single detail that's probably what it felt like to be a presidential
innovation fellow in those first few days to be like the one person who was was bringing a lot of these ideas and
philosophies into a government agency that had been around and doing something a certain way a different way for a very
long time and as you can imagine in government the idea of trying to fail
fast doesn't really work as well because you don't want to fail and if you fail and you fail to deliver a critical
service then people could end up dying and so we're all about trying to bring
sort of the idea of doing things iteratively but in you know a smart way understanding that we are working within
the context of the government and our whole mission is used human centered design and modern technology software
development practices to help the government deliver better services to the American people we have teams at the
Department of Defense the Department of Veterans Affairs the Small Business Administration the Department of
Homeland Security and then the Department of Health and Human Services which is the team that I work on and
just to give you a little bit more context in terms of what our team believes when it comes to designing for
trust in the context of health care or we really believe that the future of healthcare should be focused on
empowering patients and if you think about you know your role today when you
go to the doctor if you were to try to turn around and ask your doctor for a copy of your medical records data that
is about you they might give you a really crazy look and one of my co-workers actually did that once and
they sort of you know stared to her quite blankly and then a couple hours later us gave her a CD and I don't know
about you but I don't even have somewhere where I could put a CD today so we really think that part of this
mission should be focused on making sure that technologists and policy makers are in the same room because what often
happens when it comes to doing government technology is there's someone who works in policy
and they put together all of these requirements that are really product requirements but it's because in the
policy making process they're like hey there should be a rule for this there should be a rule for that and then you
know a couple months or even a couple years later someone actually has to implement that and it might not be technologically feasible or it just
might not make sense so one example I can tell you is for a project that my
team worked on which I'll talk to you about a little bit more later it was written into the law that a particular
part of the website had to be called the CMS web interface and there were many
other websites as a part of this program that were all technically web interfaces but this particular part of the program
had to do with you know claims submission so if it were up to us the
product people we might have just named it what it did like claim submission but we were required by law to name it
something else which didn't actually describe what it did so as you can imagine that's kind of a minor complaint
but there's sometimes more serious complaints where something could be written into law it really sets your
product strategy and you really can't fix it a couple years later when you're required also by law gentle minute so
that's a little bit more about some of the challenges that we're working with and how we're trying to get ahead of the process by being a part of that
policy-making process and for those of you who you know aren't aware Medicare
is actually the largest health insurance program in the country we serve 55 million people and the payments that go
through Medicare comprise about 3.5% of the US economy we're also the single largest payer
which means that when we do something to really advance technology in the healthcare space we're really trying to
ask the market to demand that private payers as well so we're hoping that by trying to make data more available by
trying to make patient data more accessible to them we can sort of encourage the market to demand that from
private payers as well so for those of you who aren't covered by Medicare so because Medicare you have to be 65 or
older you're probably on a private payer plan and in like the work that we do
can't directly help you get access to your medical records but we're trying to hook we're hoping that we can really
push the market to make sure that your payer is encouraged by other players in the market to do the same so now that
you have a little bit more context about what where I'm coming from what group I'm coming from and some of
the challenges that we work with that are unique to government I want to just sort of go back and talk a little bit
more about why this topic matters to me why designing for trust matters and then
I'll tell you a little bit more about three lessons that I've learned when it comes to designing for trust and I'll
walk you through how we integrated each of those lessons for a program that we launched this year called the quality
payment program and then finally I open up to questions so why does designing for trust matter
and why is this thing that seems to be my problem also a problem for all of us uh I don't know about you but I never
thought that I was actually gonna work for the government I thought that I really liked being able to create my own
rules you only get to do that that much in government um but I really think that
before I joined the government my idea of what the government was was a lot of
unpleasant experiences in my life so I thought about you know the time that I have to go to the DMV and everyone there
looks so unhappy um people who are waiting in line there and the people who
are working there um I thought about my experiences filing taxes I remember one
year you know some they were trying to get some information about me asking for more information and they mailed it to
me but I had just moved and then a kept getting mailed to me and then they sent me finally an email to log into an
online system check a message but I didn't actually know what my password was and it was really hard to reset it
and I'd call a phone number and all my experiences with the DMV with IRS they
were really pretty horrible and um I didn't love interacting with the government let alone trust it and I
think this is probably true for most people who you know in terms of their
interactions with the government the interesting thing is when I talk to people um when I'm doing a lot of user
research for a number of our projects I'm interviewing people who are interacting with the government and I'm
also entering people who are within the government who are building the systems to support those people and what I hear
often a lot is oh I don't know about that process it's another group that manages it and I
don't know about you but when I was interacting with my local DMV or I was
interacting with IRS which is at the federal level I thought of them both as the government and if I had a bad
experience at the DMV that me gave me a negative perception of how to interact
with government so that if I went to deal with another branch of government I already didn't trust it and I don't know
but I think that this is really a key difference between in the field of your user experience when we talk about
customer journey mapping and we talk when we talk about service blueprinting so I think this picture really you know
illustrates pretty well the difference between those two if you think about this in the context of a play right what
you see on the front stage or what the audience sees that's your customer journey map so for your end user
it could be someone they have to go to one place if say they're starting a new business they have to go to one office
make sure they get certain licenses they have to go in another office - maybe file some paperwork on all of these
complex interactions are their journey and what's behind that what's backstage
in this play are all those different branches of an organization that are
supporting their experience so before I worked at the USGS I worked for a start-up and in the context of our
customer journey map we thought about our customers interactions with our account management team our sales team
their interactions with our mobile app our web app and then the backstage was
all the different departments within the company who sort of helped support that experience so when it comes to trust we
didn't realize at the time but sometimes when we were building something in the
product so I was on the product team we might occasionally reference someone's
experience interacting with the sales team or the account management team but
it it actually took a while until we actually built out a document outlining
all of this that we realized that maybe they didn't trust some a certain thing because they had a bad experience with
asking a question of customer support and it really helped us bring together all these different departments to make
sure we were on the same page about how we want to design for trust what messages do we want to use for like the
error pages or the blank landing pages and was that consistent with a message that we were giving people when someone
spoke to them over the phone so you might be thinking even though I've been talking about this in the
context of government and also at a start-up you know why does this matter to you I think it it might be true that
most people have never really trusted the government but I think even particularly today you know in this year
at this time sometimes people don't really technology people don't really trust technology companies either I
think that people are really starting to question what's hidden and all those privacy policies and how can I make sure
that when I'm sharing my data people aren't using it in a weird way so I
think that it's even more critical for those of us who are working on emerging technology to think about how we design
for trust and make sure that we're disclosing information at the right time and then maybe in some cases not saying
too much in order to confuse people so
now I want to transition to telling you about three lessons that I've learned when it comes to designing for trust and
these are all related to the context of three different disciplines within user experience the first is data
visualization the second is user research and third is content strategy and one thing that I think is really
interesting is that a lot of larger user experience teams are actually hiring dedicated specialists for some of these
different disciplines even as smaller organizations try to hire generalists who know a little bit about each of
these different subjects and I'll speak to these a little bit more generally and talk about how it's relevant to a
particular project we worked on at USGS but I'm also talking about this given my current my previous background where I
worked at a tech startup and I worked with data scientists quite often in that case when we were designing for trust we
are really designing for trust in our machine learning features because a lot of people who are part of our user base
just didn't really trust that so I'll talk about some of these principles of
designing for trust a little bit in the context of that and then also in the context of designing for trust in government as well so the first lesson
that I learned when it comes to designing for trust is that often less is more
when I was at a startup I worked with a number of data scientists who had PhDs they're very highly educated and I
didn't really think about this in the context of working with them when I first started working with them but I
thought back to my experience in school when I was taking math classes and you
know you have a math problem you're supposed to find the answer and I would really jump to try to write down the
answer and then be like okay I'm done but that was never good enough because your teacher always wants you to sort of
show your work how did you get to this answer what's your reasoning for that and they really drill that mindset into
you in school you really have to show your work and when I was done with school I kind of forgot about this but
some of my colleagues that I worked with they had been in school for much longer and they some some of them came straight
out of PhD program into working in industry so this whole mindset of showing your work was a really well
engrained into them and when I was working on up and I was working on a
feature where we were trying to forecast a likelihood of something like it was a
predictive analytics feature and you could sort of go about it in a couple ways on one end of the spectrum you
could just say what your prediction was on the other end you could give the prediction and also all your reasoning
for that and for my colleagues on the data science team they really wanted to add a lot of nuance you know well it's
you know eighty five point seven percent but also because of this this and this and this is why it's different in this
state versus this other state there are a lot of details that were really matter
to them because they were thinking about justifying this for someone else who also had a PhD but for a lot of our
users they did not have a PhD and they do not care about all these details and in fact it actually confused them so we
learned pretty quickly that when it came to visualizing this data it was really important to sometimes hide the details
and make sure it was able to be found for someone who really wanted to look for it but for most people they just
wanted the answer of what we recommended I think in the context of working in government now this is also particularly
relevant because now I work with Paul's people and a lot of policy people have law degrees and in in law the details
really matter right if you've ever tried to read a piece of legislation it can
sometimes be hundreds of pages and part of those pages might just be exceptions to the particular rule so you have to
dig through all that information to find out what the law really means and I think the hard part is people who know
policy they kind of lose sight of the fact that most people don't have an interest in reading hundreds of pages to
figure out what the law means for them so it's part of our role on the user experience team within USGS to make sure
we translate some of those details into what really matters to someone else and if we're able to do that well we can
really help start to build trust in making sure that when we push out a new law we can really translate it into
stuff for someone to tell them what it means for them the second lesson that I
learned when it comes to designing for trusts is that it really it's really important to ask the right questions and
this sort of borrows from the field of user research so when we first started
to do some user research on at the startup that I was at on some of those predictive analytics features we started
to ask questions like does this make sense do you like this and we learned very quickly that these were pretty bad
questions asked and the reason for that was we wanted to answer these to these
questions but we couldn't ask them in this way because the person sitting across from you is also a human and they
look at you and they know that you've been working on this for a couple months of your life and they don't want to hurt
your feelings if they don't like this or if they wouldn't ever use it so they might sort of tell you uh maybe or they
might just say yes I like it but it might not actually accurate represent
how they feel because they don't want to hurt your feelings then we try to ask
questions because we had trouble figuring out what we wanted to name a certain feature so we might ask
questions like what would you do or what would you call this and the challenge with this is it really threw off the
rapport that had built with the user over the course of the interview because it made them really nervous our users were people who
Straub was not to name features and to ask them to do that was kind of
stressful for them it really put them on the spot and it made it harder for them
to answer some of our following questions and we also really wanted it
to answer to this but we couldn't ask it this way so what we learned was to sort of find a balance between a couple of
these questions that we are trying to ask so that we could get the answer but we would phrase the question a different way so one thing we learned was that we
really wanted to put them in the context of a situation we knew would be relevant to them for the users of the startup
that I worked at a lot of them were in organizations where there's a good
amount of turnover in their profession so we asked a question like imagine someone you just started on your team
and they're not familiar with all the tools that your organization uses how do you explain this and what it does to
them and that was a very realistic scenario it made them comfortable because they could see it happening in
their near future and they were able to answer it by saying oh well I would explain it does this and this and they
basically gave us the same phrases that we needed to understand what they would want to call it but the question was
just phrased in a different way and I think the most important thing that we learn was to listen to the questions
that users asked us so I learned that it was really important to at the start of
the interview say something like you're probably going to have questions for us because we're going to show you things
that you don't see in the product today and for all of these questions I might
respond with a question and I promise it's not because I'm trying to be annoying it's because I learned so much
from why you're asking me a particular question and I promise at the end of the interview I'll answer every single one
of those questions and it's really important to say this at the beginning because if you don't say it and you're in the middle of the interview and your
user asks you a question and you respond with a question they can get kind of annoyed with you because it's it's not
fun to have every question get the response of another shame so that was the next thing we
learned when it came to conducting a lot of these user interviews and trying to really build that trust with our users
and the last thing we learned came from the field of content strategy or UX
writing which is that writing well really matters a lot especially if you're trying to get rid of some of
those details in the context of lesson is more you really want to make sure
that you write really well to communicate what you're you want your users to find and I don't know about you
but I have always thought that if I weren't a user experience designer I would want to be a journalist because
it's kind of similar you just kind of go around talk to a lot of people and it's in a field of user experience you take
all of your insights and you might design something from that and then in the context of journalism you take all your insights and you might write
something from that so I'd always thought like this is a really great opportunity to like practice being the journalist I was never able to be but
the problem was a lot of the publications I liked reading they used kind of like very complex language and
when I first started to do a lot of writing within our product I would try to emulate some of these publications
the problem was it wasn't a good fit for the brand and it also wasn't fit for the
users goals right because if you think about like you when you use a software
product sometimes it's kind of condescending if you go to an error page and it's like too cute because what you
really want is to actually just have the page take you to where you need to go so
I really tried to think about my process now is - I write what comes to mind
naturally first and then I do like an audit where I edit it for the tone of voice and making sure it fits the brand
and I also make sure that I try to say as much as possible in as few words as possible um if you're looking for more
resources on content strategy or UX writing you're probably just searched some of those terms and come up with a
lot of resources but two resources I like recommending our plain language gov and a book called letting go the words
so no I think it probably is helpful for me to just give you a quick preview of
some of these lessons learned and how we integrated them into a project that we worked on at USGS and I'll talk a little
bit more about both my role in this and also my colleagues because a lot of them
got started on this project before I joined so what you're looking at here is
the website for a program that we launched this year called the quality payment program and for those of you who
aren't familiar with the field of healthcare for a number of years legislators have been trying to push the
healthcare industry from something called a fee-for-service model to a value-based care model and what that
means is that when you go to the doctor today what you probably experience is that for every service that you get you
get a line item and a belt for that so you get a blood test or you get an x-ray and for every single service you're
charged a particular fee now this particular model doesn't necessarily
have your interests aligned with interests of the health care system right because they could try to make more money off of you by giving you more
x-rays but you might not actually need so what the industry is trying to do is
make sure that people get paid more based on the quality of care how healthy is your patient are they getting the
services that they actually need and is that making them healthier in order for this to actually happen clinicians need
to submit data about their patients and the quality of care to the Center for
Medicare and Medicaid Services so that we can pay them accordingly so this program the quality payment
program was sort of a first step to making sure this happen in Medicare
specifically so this site is a great
example I think of that first lesson learned and that third one because we really took all those hundreds of pages
of text and we translated it into plain language for clinicians to better
understand how this law would affect them in plain language and if this
program would impact the way that they would get paid we hid the details and it's replaced them with
clear and concise copy so this really is an example of both that lessons learned
from content strategy and then also from you know making sure you're visualizing the right details the other thing that
was really critical to making sure that we designed for trust in this program was having a very comprehensive user

care agency so when we first start working with them at USDA with USGS
there weren't that many people who were familiar with the terms human centered design or user research when we

that feedback quickly we could iterate on this none of this also wouldn't

and that would be my call colleague candid Johnson she leads the UX research program at CMS and there are several

design the first thing she did was that she helped the people who were already
doing user research recognized that they were doing user research so there were people who you know aren't familiar with
a lot of the terms of our industry they were experts in understanding very detailed parts of the healthcare system
uh but they would try to get feedback because they were really dedicated career public servants they would run

the program and they didn't consider themselves user researchers but she really helped them get some of the
language describe what they did so that they could you know pattern match and think about those terms look

was that she made sure that people eating different US research efforts across organization actually talked to
each other ah so the government is really large and complex and even within the same agency
sometimes it's hard for people to realize that someone else in the same building could be working on a similar initiative so when she heard here and
there that there's one group that was trying to trying to run a diary study and another group that was trying to get

people came to her and asked for help in doing something related to use our research she never just always like did

our engagement with them over two years was able to embrace human centered design is a product that launched two
reviews like this so I gave you a quick preview of some of

the appeals benefit process and it's essentially trying to serve people who

time they weren't able to access benefits that they deserved so they're trying to build out a tool that helps

on these are testing very continuously into their process and build that trust
so that people when they're you know going through and testing some of the

if you've ever considered or even if you haven't considered working in public

gov slash join one thing I'll say that's really unique about USGS is we have a

yeah sure so um so I mentioned earlier a lot of that uh a lot of those lessons

was that this distribution chart a lot of people thought it was a time series graph so they thought it was actually

the other part that led to a little bit of mistrust was we had explanations for
why we gave certain forecast scores so we might say something like there is

written out in the same kinds of words and that when people saw some of the

three positive things and two negative things but it's still like a pretty low number like and

there waiting on in the algorithm and this at least helped build some more

yeah sure so I think that when building a you user
research program you really want to have all those different types of user research um I define them I think
there's a lot of people in industry who differentiate between three types of user research the four first is
formative um the second is generative and the third is evaluative and they roughly more or less map out to over the
stages of a product development process so formative research would be research that you do before you even build
anything it's research to help you figure out what you want to build in the first place so this is probably more heavy on
the qualitative research so that might be interviews with people it might just be you know observation following people
around and trying to observe you know the different pain points in their day and not just kind of being like a fly on the wall um
and the second stage is generative research which is I think a little bit
of like co.design with your users and the third is evaluative research which
is probably what most people think of when they think of user research so this would be usability testing um once you
have a design in place making sure that it's easy for people to use I think that in this particular in the case of the
quality payment program probably the most valuable stage was that formative
research and I think but I think that's true for a lot of projects actually it because you could throw something
together really quickly and I think this is really easy for some of my colleagues that I've worked with who have an
engineering background and they're working on projects like they know how to build anything right so they like
have an idea and they just start to build it and then after they've already sunk a lot of time and effort into
building something then they stride to get testing done on it and they realize that oh no one actually needed this and
then all that work they put into building in is is kind of for nothing you know and that's a really hard lesson
to learn after you've already put in the work of building something so I think that for any project the most important is just formative research making sure
that people actually want the thing that you're trying to build and if they don't maybe you through talking to them you'll
uncover other opportunities to build something else yeah it's also the
hardest type of user research I think any other questions
